text: as a malignant tumor grows cancer cells
can invade surrounding tissue like a
weed spreading through a garden but they
also have the potential to take root in
other parts of the body in a process
known as metastasis with metastasis
individual cancer cells break off from a
growth and travel in the body's vessels
to other organs only about one in 10,000
cancer cells take hold in other tissues
but once there they can lie dormant for
months or even years before conditions
are right for them to start multiplying
again what metastasis means is that
cancer can spread so you could get a
breast cancer that moves to the brain or
a lung cancer appearing in the liver but
even if a cancer has metastasized
there are ways of fighting back one of
the most commonly used techniques uses
medicines and it's known as chemotherapy
chemotherapy drugs are a bit like the
selective weed killers you might use in
your garden so you can rid your lawn of
weeds but leave the grass untouched
chemo agents target fast-growing cells
in the body like cancer cells killing
them leaving the slower growing healthy
cells unharmed
but cancer cells aren't the only ones
that multiply fast our blood cells made
in our bone marrow and cells in our gut
due to so chemo can also affect these
and this is what leads to side effects
like tiredness susceptibility to illness
a hair loss nevertheless chemotherapy
has helped to save millions of lives and
remains a very effective treatment for
cancer unfortunately if any disease
cells are left behind they can mutate
further or undergo other chemical
changes so they can evolve to become
resistant to chemotherapy like some
weeds are resistant to weed killer the
Institute of cancer research are working
with the Royal Marsden Hospital to
develop new drugs that target specific
cancers we might refer to them by body
part brain lung breast etc but it would
be more accurate to refer to them by
genetic coding and so far we've
identified over 200 different types of
cancer each one of them capable of
changing or mutating within the body a
lot of work is currently being done to
develop medicines based on the specific
genetic makeup and character of
particular diseases dr. yu Dai Banerjee
is currently overseeing 31 trials of new
drugs the cancer is very smart and it
actually evolves with every treatment
that you get what we have to do is to
almost place Jess with the cancer and
try and predict what it's going to do
next
very well once a drug is found to be
affected in the lab it has to be tested
with real patients already undergoing
treatment Karen is on one of dr.
Banerjee's phase 1 trials she was
diagnosed with cancer three years ago
that looks all right
everything again I was actually told the
first thing I said to my consultant was
am I going to die and she said to me I
don't know so that was like oh okay then
and so it was a it was a shock but I
took it much better than I thought I
would I always thought if you got cancer
you'd be laying in bed and you'd never
got that's how I imagine cancer to be
you know you just get on with that and
it's made me feel a lot better about
myself and Here I am three years late
you
